title: Ramen Bowl - Build Your Own

options.name: Tonkotsu (Creamy Pork Bone)

ingredients.name: Pork femurs, split to expose marrow

steps: Soak bones in cold water for 6 hours or overnight to remove blood (optional but improves color).
Add bones to fresh water, bring to boil, then simmer 15-20 minutes while skimming scum continuously. This blanch is critical for white tonkotsu.
Strain and discard blanching liquid. Scrub bones clean under running water.
Add clean bones to pot with 6L fresh water. Boil at medium heat for 18 hours, stirring frequently and adding water to maintain coverage.
If using aromatics, add in last hour of cooking.
Strain soup. For final creamy emulsion, blend soup in blender on high for 30 seconds (or use immersion blender for 5 minutes).
Yields ~3L. Use 350ml per bowl. Freezes well for 6 months.

options.name: Chicken Chintan (Clear)

ingredients.name: Chicken backs (or 2 small whole chickens, broken down)

steps: Add chicken to stockpot, cover with water.
Bring to boil briefly and skim any scum for 5-10 minutes.
Reduce heat to below simmer (88°C/190°F) and hold for 6 hours.
If using aromatics, add for final hour.
Strain and reserve. Yields ~3L clear, delicate broth. Use 350ml per bowl.

options.name: Chicken Paitan (Creamy)
steps: Add chicken parts and water to pot.
Bring to boil, then simmer and skim scum for 15-20 minutes.
Boil at medium heat for 6 hours, stirring frequently and adding water to maintain coverage.
Add aromatics and boil thoroughly for final hour.
Strain soup. Blend in blender on high for 30 seconds to finalize creamy emulsion (or immersion blend for 5 minutes).
Yields ~4L rich, creamy chicken broth. Use 350ml per bowl.

options.name: Vegetable Chintan (Vegan)
steps: Add water, onion, carrot, garlic, ginger, and shiitake to pot.
Bring to boil, then reduce to simmer.
Cook at simmer (95°C/203°F) for 1 hour.
Add green onion and kombu, turn off heat, steep 15 minutes.
Strain and reserve. Yields ~2.5L light, aromatic vegan broth. Pairs best with miso tare. Use 350ml per bowl.

options.name: Shoyu (Soy Sauce)
steps: Combine soy sauce, mirin, kombu, niboshi, and sake in sealed container.
Refrigerate 6 hours to 2 days to cold-steep.
Heat to 71°C/160°F and hold 10 minutes.
Remove and discard kombu.
Bring to 82°C/180°F (just below boil) and hold 15 minutes.
Add katsuobushi, hold at 82°C/180°F for 5 more minutes.
Add sugar, whisk to dissolve.
Strain and refrigerate up to 6 months. Use 30ml tare per 350ml broth.

options.name: Shio (Salt-Based)
steps: Combine water, kombu, and mirin in sealed container.
Refrigerate 6 hours to 2 days.
Heat to 71°C/160°F and steep 10 minutes.
Remove and discard kombu.
Add sake, bring to boil, cook 10 minutes until alcohol smell subsides.
Add salt and MSG, whisk to dissolve.
Cool before use. Stores indefinitely refrigerated. Use 30ml tare per 350ml broth.

options.name: Miso (Fermented Soybean Paste)

ingredients.name: Onion, pureed or finely grated (about 1/2 onion)

steps: Take 70g of pureed onion and add to small pan.
Cook over low heat, stirring frequently, until golden brown (20-30 minutes).
Remove from heat and place in mixing bowl to cool.
When cooled, add remaining raw onion (70g), garlic, ginger, all misos, mirin, soy sauce, sesame oil, tahini, black pepper, and tobanjan.
Whisk thoroughly to combine into smooth paste.
Refrigerate in covered container for at least 24 hours to develop flavor and mellow raw vegetables.
Keeps up to 12 months refrigerated. Use 60-70g tare per 350ml broth.

options.name: Chicken Fat (Neutral)
steps: MICROWAVE METHOD: Place chicken skin in microwave-safe bowl. Cook uncovered on high for 8 minutes. Strain fat from crispy skins.
STOVETOP METHOD: Add skin and 15-30g water to pan. Heat over medium, stirring occasionally for 45 minutes until fat renders and skin crisps. Strain.
Store refrigerated up to 6 months. Use ~15ml (1 tbsp) per bowl.

options.name: Pork Lard (Rich)
steps: If using store-bought lard, melt and use as-is. If rendering from backfat:
Preheat oven to 121°C/250°F.
Add backfat and 15-30g water to oven-safe pan.
Cook 2-3 hours until golden brown and fully rendered.
Strain and reserve. Store refrigerated up to 6 months. Use ~15ml (1 tbsp) per bowl.

options.name: Scallion Oil (Aromatic)
steps: Add oil and scallion whites to small saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until scallions turn light golden and fragrant (10-15 minutes).
Remove from heat and let cool in pot.
Strain and transfer to container. Store refrigerated up to 6 months. Use ~15ml (1 tbsp) per bowl.

options.name: Mayu (Black Garlic Oil)

ingredients.name: Oil (mix of sesame, vegetable, and lard)

steps: Mince garlic finely in food processor (or by hand to 1/8-inch pieces).
Spread mince on paper towels and squeeze out as much moisture as possible. Replace towels until dry.
Heat oil in pan. When warm, add garlic.
Cook over medium-high heat, stirring constantly, until very dark brown (almost black) and oil begins to smoke (15-20 minutes).
Strain solids, reserving oil. Lay solids on paper towels to remove excess oil until crispy and crumbly.
Add dried solids to mortar and pestle. Mash for ~5 minutes until oil escapes and forms smooth black paste.
Mix reserved oil back in to thin to desired consistency.
Store refrigerated up to 6 months. Use sparingly (~5-10ml per bowl) for visual contrast and bitter complexity.

options.name: Chili Oil (Spicy)
steps: Add fat, garlic, ginger, and onion to small saucepan.
Heat over medium-low, stirring occasionally, until ingredients turn light golden and fragrant (15 minutes).
Add togarashi, Chinese chilis, and Sichuan peppercorns.
Remove from heat and steep 30 minutes.
Strain and transfer to container. Store refrigerated up to 6 months. Use ~15ml (1 tbsp) per bowl for heat.

options.name: Chashu (Braised Pork Belly)
steps: Preheat oven to 110°C/225°F.
Heat oven-safe pot over medium. Season pork with salt and pepper.
Sear pork on all sides until golden brown (4-5 min per side). Sop up rendered fat with paper towel.
Combine mirin, soy sauce, water, brown sugar, and garlic in bowl.
Deglaze pot with sake, then add soy mixture.
Bring to boil, cover, and braise in oven 3-4 hours, turning hourly, until tender (internal temp ~93°C/200°F).
Cool in braising liquid, refrigerate until cold for easy slicing.
Slice and optionally sear before serving. Use 2-3 slices per bowl.

options.name: Soft Boiled Eggs (Marinated)
steps: Bring large pot of water to rolling boil. Prepare ice bath.
Optional: poke small hole in wider end of egg with thumbtack (prevents cracking, aids peeling).
Lower eggs into boiling water (4-6 at a time to maintain temp).
Boil 6-7 minutes, stirring gently first minute. 6 min = liquid yolk, 7 min = slightly custardy yolk.
Immediately transfer to ice bath for 15 minutes until fully chilled.
Peel eggs carefully.
QUICK BRINE: Combine equal parts soy sauce, mirin, and water. Add peeled eggs, jostle every hour, soak 4-6 hours. Remove and refrigerate.
Halve eggs before serving. Use 1/2 egg per bowl.

options.name: Green Onions (Sliced)
steps: Slice green onions into thin rings, oblong diamonds (45° angle), or fine threads.
Use both white and green parts for color contrast.
Serve raw as garnish. Use ~10g per bowl.

options.name: Menma (Bamboo Shoots)

ingredients.name: Lacto-fermented bamboo shoots (or canned as substitute)

steps: If using fermented bamboo: soak in cold water 12-24 hours in fridge. Drain thoroughly.
Add bamboo, mirin, sugar, and soy sauce to sauté pan.
Cook, stirring occasionally, until liquid slightly absorbed (10-15 minutes).
Add sesame oil to coat.
Transfer to container and refrigerate 24 hours before using. Keeps for months. Use 20-30g per bowl.

options.name: Nori (Seaweed Sheet)
steps: Cut nori sheet into rectangles or squares.
Place on edge of bowl just before serving so it stays crispy.
Use 1 sheet per bowl.

options.name: Corn (Sweet)
steps: If using frozen corn, thaw and drain.
If using canned corn, drain well.
Optional: quickly sauté in butter for extra flavor.
Sprinkle on top of finished bowl. Use ~30-50g per bowl.
PREHEAT BOWL: Fill serving bowl with boiling water. Let sit while preparing - this is critical to prevent cooling the soup.
HEAT BROTH: Bring your selected broth to 95-100°C (203-212°F) in a pot.

BOIL NOODLES: Bring large pot of unsalted water to rolling boil. Add 140g fresh noodles. Cook 1-3 minutes depending on thickness (thin: 1-2 min, medium: 2-3 min, thick: 3-4 min). Stir gently to separate.
ASSEMBLE BOWL BASE: Dump preheating water from bowl. Add your selected tare amount to empty bowl (shoyu/shio: 30ml, miso: 60-70g).
Add your selected aroma oil (~15ml or 1 tablespoon).
Pour hot broth (350ml) over tare and oil. Stir gently to combine and dissolve tare completely.
DRAIN AND ADD NOODLES: Drain noodles thoroughly, shake off excess water. Add to bowl in center, using chopsticks to arrange neatly if desired.
TOP AND SERVE: Arrange your selected toppings artfully: chashu slices, halved egg, green onions, and any additional toppings.
SERVE IMMEDIATELY while piping hot. Enjoy your custom ramen creation!

notes: MODULAR DESIGN: This recipe lets you build your perfect bowl by mixing and matching components. Each component can be made 1-7 days in advance.
POPULAR COMBINATIONS:
• Classic Shoyu: Chicken Chintan + Shoyu Tare + Scallion Oil + Chashu + Egg + Green Onions
• Rich Tonkotsu: Tonkotsu + Shio Tare + Pork Lard + Chashu + Egg + Green Onions + Mayu drizzle
• Sapporo Miso: Chicken Paitan + Miso Tare + Pork Lard + Corn + Chashu + Green Onions
• Vegan: Vegetable Chintan + Miso Tare + Scallion Oil + Corn + Green Onions + Nori
MAKE-AHEAD SCHEDULE:
• 1 week before: Make tare and aroma oil (stores for months)
• 1-2 days before: Make broth, chashu, marinated eggs
• Day of: Slice toppings, heat broth, cook noodles, assemble
BROTH NOTES:
• Chintan = clear, delicate, traditional
• Paitan = creamy, rich, emulsified from vigorous boiling
• Tonkotsu = pork bone paitan, most labor-intensive but iconic
• All broths freeze excellently for 6+ months
TARE NOTES:
• Tare provides ALL the salt - unseasoned broth is bland!
• Shoyu = soy sauce based, most versatile, classic
• Shio = salt based, lets broth flavor shine
• Miso = paste based, adds body and earthy complexity
• Typical ratio: 10% tare to broth by volume
NOODLE NOTES:
• Fresh ramen noodles must contain wheat + kansui (alkaline salts) for authentic springy texture and yellow color
• Sun Noodle brand (frozen section) is excellent and widely available
• Cook in unsalted water - the tare seasons everything
• Fresh noodles actually improve after 1-2 days rest in fridge
COMPONENT FLEXIBILITY:
• Light broth + rich tare = balanced
• Rich broth + light tare = broth-forward
• Experiment to find your perfect combination!
Source: Adapted from The Ramen_Lord Book of Ramen by Mike Satinover
